summary: This is a legal memorandum filed by Ghislaine Maxwell's defense attorneys in support of her third motion for release on bail. It proposes two new conditions: renouncing her French and British citizenship, and placing her and her spouse's assets under the monitoring of a retired federal judge. The document argues these conditions eliminate flight risk and criticizes the strength of the government's case.

persons.name: Ghislaine Maxwell
persons.context: The defendant seeking release on bail, arguing she has no intention to flee and proposes unprecedented conditions to assure her appearance.

persons.name: Bobbi C. Sternheim
persons.context: Lead attorney for Ghislaine Maxwell, signing the memorandum and representing her in the bail application.

persons.name: Christian R. Everdell
persons.context: Attorney from Cohen & Gresser LLP representing Ghislaine Maxwell.

persons.name: Jeffrey S. Pagliuca
persons.context: Attorney from Haddon, Morgan & Foreman P.C. representing Ghislaine Maxwell.

persons.name: Laura A. Menninger
persons.context: Attorney from Haddon, Morgan & Foreman P.C. representing Ghislaine Maxwell.

persons.name: William S. Duffey, Jr.
persons.role: Retired Federal Judge / Proposed Asset Monitor
persons.context: A retired federal District Court judge and former U.S. Attorney who has agreed to serve as the asset monitor for Maxwell's finances if bail is granted.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: Referenced as the person Maxwell is allegedly being used as a 'substitute replacement' for in the public narrative.

persons.name: Dominique Strauss-Kahn
persons.context: Cited as a comparative case where a French citizen with serious charges and no U.S. ties was granted bail with conditions.

connections.description: Sternheim is Maxwell's lead defense attorney, filing this bail motion on her behalf.
Everdell is listed as one of Maxwell's defense attorneys.
Pagliuca is listed as one of Maxwell's defense attorneys.
Menninger is listed as one of Maxwell's defense attorneys.
If bail is granted, Judge Duffey would monitor and have co-signing authority over Maxwell's and her spouse's assets.
Maxwell is described in the document as being depicted as a 'substitute replacement' for Epstein.

events.title: Pretrial Motion Deadline
events.description: Deadline by which Ghislaine Maxwell's defense team filed twelve pretrial motions challenging the indictment.

events.title: Filing of Third Bail Motion Memorandum
events.description: Date this memorandum in support of Ghislaine Maxwell's third motion for release on bail was filed with the court.

locations: United States District Court Southern District of New York
London (referenced regarding sale of a house)
keyFacts: Ghislaine Maxwell proposed renouncing her French and British citizenship as a condition for bail to eliminate any potential extradition protections.

Maxwell proposed placing all her and her spouse's liquid assets (except for legal fees and basic living expenses) into a new account monitored and co-signed by retired federal judge William S. Duffey, Jr.
The defense filed twelve pretrial motions by January 25, 2021, arguing they raise substantial legal issues that could lead to dismissal of some or all charges.
The memorandum argues Maxwell has been unfairly vilified in the media as a 'substitute replacement' for Jeffrey Epstein.
The defense cites the case of Dominique Strauss-Kahn as a precedent where a foreign citizen with serious charges and no U.S. ties was granted bail.
